name: Steller's Sea Eagle
description: This massive raptor is unmistakable due to its strikingly yellow and large beak. The body is dark brown to black, with only the wedge-shaped tail, wing bends, and leg feathering being white.
spread_note: Nests on Kamchatka, around the Sea of Okhotsk, north to Sakhalin, and south to the Amur River. Part of the population migrates to southern areas—Hokkaido and the Kuril Islands.
food_note: Mainly fish, also birds, crabs, octopuses, or carrion
image_alt: Steller's Sea Eagle, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 74–81 cm; tail length 33 cm; wingspan 118–136 cm; weight 5–9 kg
attractions: It builds its nest from sticks in tall trees, occasionally on rocky cliffs or forested slopes. A pair typically has 2–3 nests in its territory, used alternately. When hunting fish, it either circles about 5 meters above the water before diving or stands in shallow water.
projects_note: Its population is estimated at just 5,000 individuals and continues to decline, primarily due to pollution and habitat changes (dam construction, oil extraction, fishing). It is listed as vulnerable on the IUCN Red List.
breeding: The first Steller’s sea eagle lived at Prague Zoo from 1952–1976, the second from 1958–1959. The species vanished from our exhibits for a long time until a female arrived from Almaty in 2000, joined by a male from Liberec Zoo in 2006. The pair raised their first chick in 2007 and has nested successfully in subsequent years, even repeatedly raising two chicks.
